desc: The blade-spined patriarch whose body was a living arsenal. His bones grew as serrated plates, each one sharp enough to split stone, and elders claim he could shed shards of himself to create new weapons of war.

name: Carvathus
desc: The cutting lord whose wings carved canyons across continents. Every beat of his flight carried a slicing gale, and legends say he carved the first valleys simply by soaring low over the earth.

name: Prismadon
desc: The prism-titan whose crystalline coils shattered mountains with a single strike. His body refracted sunlight into searing beams of color that split stone, and the shimmering caverns of the oldest ranges are remnants of his nesting sites.

name: Burnfyre
desc:
Burnfyre was the first child of Tala, a towering fey spirit shaped from living stone rather than flesh. His body was rough granite veined with amber light, and when he moved the sound was like boulders grinding in a dry riverbed. The name Burnfyre never referred to flame. It referred to the heat of his nature, the smoldering pride and volcanic anger that simmered inside him. He was a stone bear whose eyes glowed like embers trapped behind crystal. Even among the archfey he was singular, a being who carried the weight of mountain age and the temperament of a storm held barely in check.
As the Archfey of Autumn he ruled the season of endings with the steadiness of rock and the inevitability of falling leaves. His presence shifted forests into their dying colors, and the land responded to him as if he were gravity given form. Burnfyre’s anger was not wild. It was tectonic. Slow to rise, unstoppable once awakened. Spirits whispered that he shared ancient kinship with the primal wolf Fenris, both descending from an early era when the world’s great beasts shaped themselves out of raw matter. Fenris formed from cold breath and hunger. Burnfyre from stone, pressure, and pride.
His fall came not at the hands of gods but mortals. A band of raiders, armed and emboldened by blessings from Bøsk, confronted him during the quiet turn of the season. They used weapons honed for killing things far larger than themselves. Burnfyre fought with the endurance of a mountain, but even stone can crack under enough force and cunning. When he fell, the forests dimmed and the ground carried his last tremor for miles. Autumn has never felt entirely stable since. Some believe shards of his stone body still hum with his memory, and that the bloodline of Fenris remembers him in ways mortals cannot name.

name: Ymir
desc:
Ymir was the first chill in the world and the first thaw. Born of Kistar’s stillness and Tala’s wandering spirit, Ymir carried both frost and renewal in their marrow. Their breath shaped the earliest storms, and their footsteps coaxed the first green shoots from barren earth. Some called them Breaker of the Cold, others whispered Springmint, because wherever Ymir lay their head, ice cracked open and something new tried to live.
In the age before ages Ymir crossed paths with Noh. Their companionship made the older spirits uneasy. Ymir was steady, colossal, and literal to a fault. Noh was clever in a way that felt inevitable, a force that could not be diverted. The two wandered together for a time, shaping things out of boredom and curiosity. One of those creations was Fenris.
The stories of Fenris’s birth rarely agree. Some insist Ymir sought a guardian. Others say Noh whispered ideas into Ymir’s ear until the creature gained teeth it never should have had. Noh himself tells a different story every time he speaks on the matter. One tale claims he tugged at Ymir’s shadow until it split. Another says he challenged Ymir to imagine something the gods would be unable to control. The quietest version says Ymir wanted someone large enough to converse with without stooping.
Whatever truth hides beneath the myths, Fenris came from both of them, shaped from cold breath and wild spirit, and no god ever fully claimed the creature.
Ymir is gone now. Their body became mountains, rivers, and deep-rooted forests. In the far north, when the air grows still enough to sting, some swear they can hear Ymir’s final heartbeat rolling through the ice. Age did not make Ymir invincible, but it made them wise. They understood that beginnings call for endings, and they walked toward their own with calm acceptance.
Their end came from Nasius, a distant descendant through Fenris’s bloodline. Nasius rose in secret, drawing strength from the same ice that once bent to Ymir’s will. In the final struggle they tore Ymir’s lifeforce from their fading body and claimed it as their own. Now Nasius sits upon the Frozen Throne, a monarch crowned by a legacy they stole. The north answers to them, but it has not forgotten whose throne it truly was.
